Summer Season.description: NEW DELHI: Google on Friday celebrated the longest day of the year in Northern Hemisphere by dedicating a doodle. Also called summer solstice, or midsummer, the longest day occurs when one of the Earth's poles has its maximum tilt toward the Sun. What: The longest day (and shortest night) of the year in the Northern Hemisphere. When: Today (June 21). Technically, the solstice occurs when the sun is directly over the imaginary Tropic of Cancer or 23.5°N latitude. In 2019, this will occur at 3:54 pm GMT on Friday (or 9:24 pm IST). Why: The term 'solstice' comes from Latin —'sol' means sun and 'sistere' means to stand still. How: The 23.4° tilt in the Earth's axis causes varying amounts of sunlight to reach different regions during its year-long orbit around the Sun. Today, the North Pole is tipped more towards the Sun than on any other day of the year. However, that does not mean more heat or that the Earth is any closer to the Sun, per common misconceptions. Which: Summer solstices happen twice each year (once in each hemisphere). Summer solstice for the Northern Hemisphere = Winter solstice for the Southern Hemisphere, and vice-versa. Also, during Equinoxes (vernal and autumnal), the Sun shines directly on the Equator and the length of day and night are nearly equal in either hemisphere. Key dates for 2019 (Northern Hemisphere)Spring Equinox: Wednesday, March 20 Summer Solstice: Friday, June 21 Autumn Equinox: Monday, September 23 Winter Solstice: Sunday, December 22 FYI: The longest day of the year was the reason why Narendra Modi chose June 21 as the International Day of Yoga. In Chhattisgarh, post on power woes draw.description: RAIPUR: Congress-ruled Chhattisgarh arrested a man for sedition under IPC 124A for a social media post on power cuts. It triggered a storm of criticism, and the charge was revoked on Friday on the orders of chief minister Bhupesh Baghel, who told police to ensure that it isn't repeated.  The controversy began with a Rajnandgaon resident, Mangilal Agrawal, posting a video of his on various social media platforms on Wednesday, criticising the Congress government for frequent interruptions in power supply in Chhattisgarh. He alleged that the power cuts were deliberate, as a ploy to boost inverter sales .  The video went viral. State power holding company chairman Shailendra Shukla forwarded it to company legal advisor N K P Singh, who advised legal action. An FIR was filed and Agrawal was arrested on Thursday. He was charged under IPC 124A for sedition and IPC 505 (intent to incite any class or community to commit offence against any other class or community). Both of them are non-bailable . What made the arrest even more controversial was that ahead of Lok Sabha election, Congress had sought votes on its pledge to abolish the British-era law.  The arrest sparked outrage on social media. "Congress had promised to repeal the sedition law, yet its government is misusing it. If spreading rumours is such a serious offence, then several Congressmen should have been put behind bars by now," said BJP MP from Rajnandgaon, Santosh Pandey.  Chief minister Bhupesh Baghel issued a statement, disapproving of the police action. Within hours, police dropped the sedition charge. Baghel said he and his government "vouch for freedom of expression".  However, Agrawal is still in custody as he faces charges under IPC 505. "Power supply is affected due to various factors, including natural causes like strong winds. But some people are spreading false information that it's due to some kind of a 'deal' with inverter companies. This is totally false," said power companies' chairman Shailendra Shukla. Bilaspur science club gets national reco.description: RAIPUR: In a boost to state science and development, a school-based science club - Dr Kalam Science Club of Govt Multipurpose School, in Bilaspur have been upgraded to silver club under Vigyan Prasar Network (VIPNET). The list was released by the Union department of science and technology last week. Besides, two other science clubs-Nature Bodies of Bharat Mata English School, Bilaspur and Shri Sai Polytechnic Science Club in Durg, have also been upgraded to bronze clubs. Speaking to TOI, Dr Dhananjay Pandey, coordinator of Dr Kalam Science Club, said that post the upgradation to silver club, they will now be eligible to participate in national level workshops organised by Vigyan Prasar. The club would also be entitled to activity kits of Vigyan Prasar, a digital calculator embossed with VIPNET logo, set of DVDs/ books related to science activities. Similarly, the clubs making to the bronze category would also receive all activity kits of Vigyan Prasar, and a Pen embossed with VIPNET logo and club ID. Pandey said that they submitted 40 projects prepared by the students last year. The reports underwent three stages of evaluation process and then, were finally selected for the upgradation. Of 72 science clubs of Chhattisgarh registered with VIPNET of Science Clubs, the Bilaspur-based Dr Kalam club is the first one to enter the silver category. Six students- Gaurav Mahto, Swastik Prajapati and Yaman Kumar Nirmalkar who have represented India in International Robotics Competition held in Dubai last year, and Shubham Yadav, Aniket Gandharwa and Yogesh Das who have recently passed their class 12th will get 100 percent fee waiver for pursuing engineering graduation course at Lakhmi Chand Institute of Technology (LCIT) Bilaspur. Meanwhile, a case study of Atal Tinkering Lab Government Higher Multipurpose Senior Secondary School of Bilaspur, was featured in the Atal Tinkering Lab Handbook-Nayee Dishayein Naye Nirmaan Naya Bharat, released this year by NITI Ayog. Narendra Modi.description: RANCHI: Appealing to people to take yoga to all sections of society, Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said yoga is above everything, as he performed various asanas with around 40,000 enthusiasts at the Prabhat Tara ground here to mark the fifth International Day of Yoga. Modi also urged people to make yoga an integral part of life. International Yoga Day 2019: PM urges country to embrace Yoga"We should make efforts to take yoga from cities to villages and tribal areas. Yoga is above religion, caste, colour, gender and region, it is above everything," he told the gathering. Yoga is ancient and modern. It is constant and evolving. For centuries, the essence of Yoga has remained the same… https://t.co/isvMOUTrn8— PMO India (@PMOIndia) 1561080804000The main event for the yoga day was held at the Jharkhand capital. Best pictures from International Yoga Day 2019"It (yoga) is constant and evolving for centuries. The essence of yoga has been stable and remained the same -- healthy body, stable mind, spirit of oneness. Yoga has provided a perfect blend of knowledge, karma and bhakti," the prime minister said. Events to mark the day are being held across the globe and in India, several of them are being led by Union ministers, including Amit Shah and Rajnath Singh. Modi also said the government has been working to make yoga a pillar of preventive healthcare. Follow live updates: International Yoga DayThe main event for the yoga day was held at the Jharkhand capital. Amit Shah credits PM for taking yoga to the world"It (yoga) is constant and evolving for centuries. The essence of yoga has been stable and remained the same -- healthy body, stable mind, spirit of oneness. Yoga has provided a perfect blend of knowledge, karma and bhakti," the prime minister said. Events to mark the day are being held across the globe and in India, several of them are being led by Union ministers, including Amit Shah and Rajnath Singh. Modi also said the government has been working to make yoga a pillar of preventive healthcare. Expressing concern that young people are becoming vulnerable to heart ailments, Modi said, "Yoga can play a huge role in tackling the issue and hence, this year's theme is 'Yoga for Heart'." "It is painful to read about alcoholism, substance abuse, diabetes and other things, adding yoga offers a solution to these problems," he added. He stressed that for yoga to become popular, infrastructure for it must be strengthened and said the government was working towards it. "Peace and harmony are related to yoga. People across the world must practice it," Modi said. The prime minister had arrived in Ranchi on Thursday night. On his way out of the venue, Modi shook hands with several participants, including school children, who reached out to the prime minister over barricades. The International Day of Yoga is being celebrated annually on June 21 since 2015. Yoga Day.description: The world marks the fifth edition of International Day of Yoga on June 21, 2019. Prime Minister Narendra Modi hosted the main event in Ranchi and performed yoga along with 18,000 people. It was on September 27, 2014 that PM Modi proposed a dedicated day for Yoga to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). In 2015, the first International Day of Yoga was observed. Maharashtra Lok Sabha Constituencies.description: MUMBAI: Maharashtra, which has 48 parliamentary constituencies, will go to polls in four phases, starting April 11. In 2009 and 2014, Lok Sabha elections were held in three phases in Maharashtra On April 11, seven constituencies in Maharashtra’s Vidarbha region will go to polls - Nagpur, Wardha, Yavatmal-Washim, and the naxal-affected areas of Gadchiroli and Chandrapur. In the second phase on April 18, 10 constituencies - including three constituencies in Vidarbha, six in Marathwada and Solapur in western Maharashtra - go to elections. The third phase, on April 23, of polling will be held in Pune, Baramati, Jalgaon, Jalna, Aurangabad, Raigad and Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg, Sangli, Satara and Kolhapur. In the final phase on April 29, all six constituencies in Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Palghar and Bhiwandi will go to polls among the total 17 seats in the state. KEY CONSTITUENCIESAmong the key constituencies are Baramati and Nagpur featuring high-profile candidates such as Supriya Sule and Nitin Gadkari. Then there is Ahmednagar from where Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, is contesting. Other important constituencies are Jalna, Chandrapur, Dhule, Beed, Sangli, Mumbai North Central, Mumbai North and Baramati.    CONSTITUENCIES CONTENDERS   Chandrapur Union MoS Hansraj Ahir (BJP); Suresh Dhanorkar (Congress)   Baramati Kanchan Kul (BJP); Supriya Sule (Congress)   Jalna State BJP chief Raosaheb Danve BJP; Vilas Keshavrao Autade (Congress)   Akola Sanjay Dhotre (BJP); Hidayat Patel (Congress)   Bhiwandi Kapil Patil(BJP); Suresh Kashinath Taware (Congress)    Nagpur Union minister Nitin Gadkari (BJP)   Ahmednagar Sujay Vikhe Patil (BJP)   Dhule Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre (BJP)    Beed Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter Pritam (BJP); Bajrang Sonawane (NCP)   Sangli Sitting MP Sanjay Patil (BJP)    Mumbai North Central Poonam Mahajan (BJP)    Aurangabad Subhash Zambad (Congress)   Gadchiroli Ashok Nete (BJP)   Mumbai North Gopal Shetty (BJP)    Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Tejashwi Yadav.description: PATNA/ BHAGALPUR: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in Bihar legislative assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav kicked off the Lok Sabha election campaign on Monday by addressing public meetings at Gaya, Banka and Bhagalpur in support of the Mahagathbandhan candidates. Close aides of Tejashwi said he is expected to address around 200 election meetings across the state over the next two months. “Tejashwi is the face of RJD and the star campaigner of Mahagathbandhan. He will be canvassing for candidates of all the Mahagathbandhan constituents — RJD, Congress, RLSP, HAM(S) and VIP. Thus, he will be addressing three to four election meetings every day,” Tejashwi’s political adviser Sanjay Yadav told TOI on Monday. Canvassing for RJD candidate Shailesh Kumar alias Bulo Mandal from Bhagalpur, Tejashwi came down heavily on NDA governments at the Centre and in state. He accused PM Narendra Modi of making false promises and propaganda to win the 2014 general election. “It won’t be repeated in the ensuing Lok Sabha elections,” Tejashwi said while raising questions about employment scenario and issues of Vijay Malaya, Nirav Modi, Mehul Chowksi and others who fled the country after swindling money from banks in India. Criticizing Nitish for snapping ties with RJD in 2017, Tejashwi said there was acute shortage of fertilizers, while the health services were also in a poor state. He accused deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi of protecting those involved in the multi-crore Srijan scam in Bhagalpur and some other districts. Urging the audience to vote for the RJD candidate, Tejashwi said the Bhagalpur voters had showed a mirror to Modi by voting for RJD in 2014. “They should do the same this election as the NDA government stands exposed,” he said. Political observers feel Tejashwi has become a good orator, especially after coming out of power in July 2017 when CM Nitish Kumar snapped ties with RJD-led Mahagathbandhan and rejoined BJP-led NDA. “Though not as good as his father in terms of having a rustic touch, Tejashwi is a good orator in terms of eloquence,” said DM Diwakar, political observer and professor at AN Sinha Institute of Social Studies. Maoist set ablaze tendu leaves, huge cac.description: RAIPUR: Maoists in Chhattisgarh's Gariyaband district set ablaze stock of tendu leaves worth Rs 9 crore late on Tuesday. The ultras kept on hostage three guards deployed at the godown premises, and breaking the locks of one of the warehouse, they put on fire nearly 1,700 ruck sacks stuffed with tendu leaves . Police said that the incident took place in the village of Nawamguda at the warehouse where the forest produce tendu leaves are stocked up for supply. There are three godowns owned by Forest Department for storing tendu leaves. Tendu leaves are used to wrap tobacco and used as 'beedi'. Police added that more than a dozen armed Maoists appeared fromt eh darkness of forest late on Tuesday around 2330 hours and got hold of the guards on duty. While few of them kept the guards on hostage others went towards one of the three godowns with kerosene oil and match boxes. They broke open the locks and set ablaze 1700 ruck sacks full with tendu leaves. It took minutes for fire to engulf the whole godown and the dry leaves turned into ashes while the premise was gutted. The stock of leaves were worth Rs 9 crore. The rebels escaped the spot and left the guards locked inside a room to prevent them informing police immediately. After efforts of few hours, when the guards came out of the room, they informed fire brigade police and forest official and the spot of incident taken over by the fire department which was further sealed for inquiry. As it is peak of summer, the fire took long to get doused till Wednesday morning. The remaining stock of tendu leaves will be shifted to some other warehouse, police said. The Maoists also have left a leaflet that alleges the villagers who go for collection of tendu leaves in forests were not getting proper and full payment for the work they do, therefore the stock was put on fire. However, the stock belongs to a local contractor who was being questioned by the police. However, police said that efforts were being made to keep Maoists at bay who indulge in extortion of money from contractors for collection of tendu leaves, which is why the rebels were upset and have tried to create terror. The Manpur Naxal Divisional Committee is behind the incident, police said addingt hat searching was on to nab the accused. Subsequently, Gariyaband police successfully recovers a huge cache of arms and ammunition at a Maoist camp in forest. Based on input about presence of Maoists in the region, a team of district police went on an anti-Maoist operation in forests of Manpur on the mountains of Tarjhaar when they spotted a bunker of Maoists which had huge cache of arms and ammunition including an indigenous rocket launcher. Police said that two muzzle loading guns, one air gun, one country revolver, five gelatin wire, 12 bore rifle, eight live bombs and equipment to make weapons along with explosives were recovered from the spot. This shows that Maoists were present on the spot few moments ago and they might have escaped on being informed by local villagers about police approaching their camp, a police official said. Police have sounded alert int he region and the operations were intensified. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .
